how do you build conversational apps using Amazon
Lex before we get into that I'd like to take a couple of minutes and go through some of the Core Concepts involved while
building a bot a bot or conversation app is nothing
but a collection of intent an intent performs an action in response to an
natural language user input right so the example of an intent would be I want to book a hotel right what does the user
want to do I want to book a car tell me what the weather is all these would be
intent utterances utterances are the exact phrases that your customers are going to
say for example in order to book a hotel they could say that same phrase in many
different ways I would like to book a hotel I want to to book a hotel could you make a reservation please and so
on and Lex takes those sample utterances and then builds a model out of it we'll
talk more uh when we get to that section and then there's slots slots are the pieces of data that
you need in order to fulfill the intent of your customer for example if you book
a hotel you need to know what the location is on which day what the check-in time is and so
on fulfillment once you had the conversation you collected all the data you need to be
able to run the business logic and actually make the booking right and the backend systems and that's what we mean
by fulfillment here's the flow of
how a Lex bot processes user input for example user says book a hotel in New
York City the speech recognition will will take that and convert that into
text or if they're chatting then we directly get the text input the natural language understanding
will use the intent and Slot model that you buil on the console or through the
SDK to understand what the intent is so it understands that okay hotel booking
is the intent and the user has provided the destination city and it's New York
City then figures out what else is
missing checkin date and check out date and then goes through the entire process
and at the end of it Lambda is where the business logic will get run and the
hotel booking uh actually gets done and on the way back we use Amazon poly which
is our text to speech solution it has 24 languages and 47 voices
and we'll talk a little bit about poly uh at the end of this
presentation slot elicitation The Interchange between Lex
and the user is what we call a slot illustration where Lex is trying to get the information it needs from the user
for example when they say I would like to book a hotel Lex response was sure
which city will you be traveling to in order to get that destination city and
so on so that's what we mean by slot elicitation conversation
context in order to have a engaging uh conversation with your users you need to
be able to maintain the context let's say um they said show me my sales report
in the US east region and then the next intent was hey tell me me my top
customers in that case they've already told you what region they're interested in so you could respond back with your
top customers in the US east region are X Y and Z and if they want to change the
region they will always have the option of saying well I want to know my top
customers in the US west region and then you run it with the US West because now
the new context that they provided has fresher data
and the developer has full control over this process uh of managing the
context Dynamic conversation flow many customers worry how can I stay in
control of this conversation let's say I decide to take the user to a completely
different conversation in the middle of fulfilling an intent how do I do that
with Lex youve always in control because we provide you a Lambda that can be
invoked at every turn of the conversation and using this Lambda you
can provide instructions to the nlu engine to either elicit a certain slot
or shift to a different intent for example when you say d in or
take out if they say take out then you probably go to a different intent if they say d in you stay in the current
intent you also have an ability to chain intents for example a customer just
booked a flight ticket you want to now ask them if they want to make a hotel reservation or a car
reservation you can do that declaratively on the Amazon Lex
console and if they say no I'm not interested Lex will just exit gracefully
and say okay thank you thank you dialog
management let's say your customer said I would like to book tickets to New York
City but then if you remember the screen where we showed all the different slots New York
City is the first slot that you're supposed to prompt the customer for but because they already gave you
that data you should not ask them for that data in this use case and that's where
dialog management comes into play it figures out what data has already been provided and appropriately
prompts the user for the next piece of data that is required some customers may also give
you the date saying book a flight to New York City on a certain date in that case
dialog management will neither ask for the city nor will it ask for the date it'll go straight
to um uh you know which Airlines or which category of airfare do you want me
to book or is it a return
flight you can customize your conversations so the Lambda that I spoke about which gets involved at every turn
of the conversation can also be used in order to do things like customization or
personalization of uh the user experience let's say they said I would like to book a hotel you can say would
you prefer to stay in downtown this time as well because you know that last time they booked a hotel in the downtown
area and then you can also do things like validating user input because you
don't want to go through the whole conversation before figuring out that there's no hotels uh in that area on the
date that the user specified so you can quickly validate
and get back to the user saying sorry we do not have availability on the 19th of
April error handling a very important part of having
an engaging user conversation is to be able to handle
errors and you can declaratively specify the error message that your Bot should
use as well as a hang up phrase after try and also the number of times it
should try providing that error message you can also specify multiple
error messages so that it doesn't sound like a bot you don't want your Bot to
